ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I think that the course made me more open-minded about how to approach writing. I learned that writing is really about discovery and the process might even prompt more questions than answers as you develop your thoughts and argument. I also learned that writing is kind of like a conversation maybe with yourself in some cases but with other sources as you develop your argument. From this course, I have a greater appreciation of writing and don't find it as daunting as before.

I learned how to write in the format of papers more comfortably and also how to revise my drafts better with feedback from my instructor and peers. For example, I learned to write more freely (in contrast to the high school 5 paragraph essay) based on a question, thinking as I write. Also, I was able to improve my style of writing and become more aware of the problems of my writing to focus on as I improve in revising as well. For this writing seminar especially, I was also able to examine the topic of time from the different angles of memory, identity, metaphysics, and literature. I gained a deeper understanding of time and its interaction with humans.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I felt like there were times when I would want more big group discussions in class especially during Memento or some of the readings such as the one on Capitalism. Sometimes I felt like we were looking for a specific takeaway or summary and there would be no room for further discussion on the readings. I felt like the Japanese poetry discussion was pretty good and I felt like there was room to discuss and participate.

Strengths:
- The topic that we discussed and wrote about are quite interesting (for instance, the interaction between memory and identity)
- The materials we used to examine the topic of time are also quite nice, I especially enjoyed the movies we watched
- The feedback from peers and our instructor was quite helpful for revision
Weaknesses:
- The discussions are not as efficient and engaging (a bit too scattered)
- There could have been more content that we could've explored
How to improve:
- Choose more materials that delve into the topic of time more deeply
- Make classroom discussions more focused, control time a bit more (rather than giving too much time to discuss limited material)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student who wants to fulfill their writing requirements and has qualms about the time. I think ENGL 114 specifically makes you appreciate writing especially if you think it isn't your strong suit - speaking as a STEM major.

If the topic of time interests you and you need to practice your writing more, I would recommend this course. However, if you are more interested in just improving your writing or you're more eager to discuss, there may be better writing seminars that will engage you more.
